Award.AwardTitle: AGS-PRF: Peroxy Radical (RO2) Reactivity through Functionalized Organic Iodides
Award.AbstractNarration: This project involves laboratory experiments to better characterize the reactive chemistry of peroxy radicals in the atmosphere. Peroxy radicals are key intermediate species in the production of secondary organic aerosol and ozone, which are detrimental to human health and affect climate. A flow tube will be used in the laboratory to study peroxy radical reactions under many different environmental conditions. A better understanding of this chemistry has implications for modeling air quality and for informing policy decisions on mitigating air pollution levels that may be harmful to human health.<br/><br/>The objectives of this research are: (1) to determine the effects of molecular structure and degree of functionalization on isomerization rates and dimerization products of peroxy radicals (RO2); (2) to determine the organic nitrate yield and alkoxy radical fate of functionalized RO2 species; and (3) to determine the branching ratio of hydroperoxides (ROOH) and OH in RO2-HO2 reactions where the RO2 radical is functionalized. The first objective involves probing RO2 unimolecular reactions and RO2-RO2 reactivity and determining the relative importance of each process. The second objective includes probing RO2-NO reactivity and evaluating the relative rates between these reactions and the isomerization reactions described in the Objective 1. The third objective will help to assess the hypothesis that the yield of OH increases as the degree of functionalization increases in RO2- HO2 reactions. In clean environments, where bimolecular lifetimes are long, multiple isomerization reactions might lead to RO2 species that are very functionalized and more likely to yield OH when reacting with HO2 than to form peroxides. The results from these experiments will provide fundamental experimental data on isomerization rates and branching ratios of bimolecular reactions of RO2 necessary to understand atmospheric oxidation. The success of this research will lead to the improved modeling of oxidation processes, under the conditions of both “high” and “low" NOx environments, thereby helping to improve predictions of both air quality and climate change.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied the reaction pathways of individual organic peroxy radicals (RO2) using synthetized organic iodides as precursors. RO2 species are naturally formed during atmospheric oxidation of volatile organic compounds (VOC). RO2 species have a large number of reaction pathways and the RO2 fate determines the product distributions and yields of secondary pollutants such as ozone and particulate matter. These pollutants are known to have impacts on health, visibility and climate. Incomplete understanding of RO2 reactivity hinders our ability to accurately predict pollutant concentrations in real time, enact appropriate mitigation strategies and estimate how future changes in atmospheric conditions will impact air quality.

VOC oxidation generates a large mixture of products and RO2 species which makes it difficult to study the reaction pathways of individual RO2 species. This project addressed this challenge by synthetizing specific organic iodides with varying functional groups. The photolysis of these organic iodides leads to the formation of specific RO2 and enables the direct study of their chemistry. The first part of the project focused on establishing synthetic pathways and performing the synthesis of these compounds as well as their characterization. During the second part of the project, we photolyzed these organic iodides and observed their products. The product distribution was affected by the structure of the RO2 as well as the incident light which has implications for traditional VOC oxidation experiments.

The postdoctoral research fellow supported by this project was exposed to a variety of synthesis techniques, advanced analytical instrumentation, mentored graduate and undergraduate researchers, participated in teaching and attended research conferences which are key activities for career advancement. The results of the experiments performed during this project will be published in due course.  

 


Last Modified: 06/28/2023
Modified by: Jean C Rivera-Rios
